B44: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have played the Sicilian. The Sicilian is the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. It fell out of favour when some of the world's leading players rejected it. The most frequent continuation is 3...Nf6 4.Be2, when 4...Nxe4? loses to 5.Qa4+ and likewise 4 ...Nc4?: loses to 6 d5 and 7a4+. 2.d3 signals White's intention to develop along King's Indian Attack lines, and usually transposes to the Closed Sicilian. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.Nf3. The drawback of 2.e5 is that no additional pressure is brought to the centre. The Sicilian Defence has more codes than any other opening. The Wing Gambit is generally considered too reckless, and rarely seen in grandmaster praxis. GM Joe Gallagher calls it "a forgotten relic, hardly having set foot in a tournament hall since ... well, not a lot"  c3 Sicilian is popular. Players usually enter the Grand Prix Attack by playing 2Nc4 before 3f3 or 3f4.
D12: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. It was analyzed as early as 1590, but not explored extensively until the 1920s. Many masters of Slavic descent helped develop the theory of this opening, including Alapin, Alekhine and Bogoljubov. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also try the following alternatives:4.Qc2 or 4.Qb3. Another way to play is 4...Bg4. White's sharpest try against 4...dxc4 is the Slav Geller Gambit, 5.e4. With 5.a4, White acts against ...b5 and prepares 6.e 4 and 7.Bxc4. Black's main move is 5...Bf5.

D23: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6 (the Slav Defense) Black usually allows the pawn to be recaptured and uses the time expended to play against White's centre. 3.e4 is an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre. 3.e3 prepares immediate recovery of the pawn and has often been employed by strong players, including Anatoly Karpov. 3. Nc3 was recommended by Keene and Jacobs in their opening repertoire for White. The queen check by 3.Qa4+ Nc6 4.Nf3 will quickly regain the pawn with Qxc4. 3...e5, 3...Nf6, and 3...a6 are all reasonable replies.

D70: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4, giving White an imposing central pawn duo. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school, which was coming to the fore in the 1920s, held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the Exchange Variant with White. Grünfeld Gambit (Gambit, 1998) The Grunfeld for the Attacking Player (Batsford, 2002) An Expert's Guide to the 7.Bc4 Gruenfeld (Chess Stars, 2006) Play the Grünfield (Everyman Chess, 2007)

B19: Classical Variation: 1.e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Bf5 5. Ng3 Bg6 6. h4 h6 7. Nf3 Nd7 8. h5 Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10.Qxd3. Although White's pawn on h5 looks ready to attack, it can prove a weakness in an endgame. Viktor Korchnoi played 5...exf6 many times (including his first world championship match with Anatoly Karpov), and this line has also been employed by Ulf Andersson. The 3...Bf5 variation that follows 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 has gained popularity after having been widely regarded as inferior for many years. The Panov–Botvinnik Attack begins with the move 4.c4. The Fantasy Variation aims to exploit White's weaknesses on the a7–g1 diagonal. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. After the moves 1.e4 c6 2.Nc3 d5 3.Qf3!? (Goldman Variation), White's position is sound according to Graham Burgess. The percentage white wins, black wins or a draw occurs in the games of highly rated players (2200+ FIDE) in four lines of the Caro–Kann Defence. Other lines are ineffective or doubtful.

B21: The Sicilian Defence is one of the most popular openings in chess. It is used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. After 1.e4 c5 there are three options for Black: 2...d6, 2...Nc6, and 2...e6. The Smith-Morra Gambit is named after Pierre Morra and Ken Smith, who helped popularize the opening. Black can either castle kingside with 7.Bb3 a6 or 8.0-0 (the Fischer–Sozin Attack) Black can also try Benko's move 6...Qb6, which forces White to make a decision over the d4-knight. The critical test of Black's move order is 5.c4, the Maróczy Bind. After 1.e4 c5 2.Nf3, Black has some less commonly played options apart from 2...d6, 2...Nc6 and 2...e6. White's strongest reply is to chase the knight by 3.e5 Nd5 4.Nc3 and now (a) 4...Nxc3. Many lines transpose to the Open Sicilian, the Moscow Variation or the Rossolimo Variation. White can play the positional 5.Bb5, threatening to double Black's pawns with Bxc6. The Sicilian Defence is classified under the codes B20 through B99. White may decline the gambit with 3. nc3, called the "Toilet Variation", so named after its reputed place of invention.
D48: The Semi-Slav Defense is a variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined chess opening. It is defined by the position reached after the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 c63. Nf3 Nf64. Nc3 e6. After the move order 1.d4 d5 2.c4 c6 3.Nc3 Black has the opportunity to respond with 3...e6 instead of 3...Nf6. This "triangle setup" opens up some new alternatives for both players on the fourth move. The Meran Variation is one of the main variations of the Semi-Slav. White plays 6.Bd3, provoking the continuation 6...dxc4 7.Bxc4 b5. The line was first played in 1906 in the game Schlechter–Perlis. The variation takes its name from the town of Meran in northern Italy. 8...Bb7 was long considered virtually unplayable due to the line 9.e4 b4 10.Na4 c5 11.e5 Nd5 12.Nxc5 Nxc5 13.dxc5 Bxc5 14.Bb5+ and the black king will be stuck in the center. But after 14...Ke7 Black is completely fine and might be even better, with a very strong knight on d5 and strong bishops aiming at the White kingside. Black keeps his c-pawn on c5 is: 11...Qc7 12.dxe6 fxe6 13.Ng5 Qc6 after which there are many different ways to continue for both sides. White's strategic idea in the Meran is to push e3–e4, and with a bishop on d6 Black is always ready to meet this with e6–e5, and typically Black is doing fine after such moves. Most often White players choose the move 7.Bd3. Karpov first played 7.Be2 but it soon transpired that the d3-square gives White better chances. Play often continues 12.dxe5 Nxe5 13.Nxe5 Bxe5 14.h3 with some slight advantage for White. If Black simply takes the pawn with 7...Nxg4, White will respond with 8.Rg1. Black now has a number of playable continuations, including Qf6, Nxh2, f5, h5 and Nh6. The Moscow Variation 5...h6 6.Bxf6 Qxf6 gives rise to play of a very different character. Botvinnik Variation is probably one of the most complicated of all chess openings. The opening was introduced by Mikhail Botvinnink in 1945. The game typically continues 6...dxc4 7.e4 (note: 7.a4 to prevent Black's b5 does not work) The Botvinnik Variation was invented by Klaus Junge, but he was not the first person known to have played it. Black makes the thematic pawn capture 5...dxc4 immediately. White will fianchetto his king bishop and castle kingside, while Black will play ...c5, ...Qb6, castle queenside. More than 90% of games continue with 5.Bg5 or 5.e3, but there are some sidelines that are worth a quick look. The move 5.Qb3 is an alternative way of protecting the c-pawn. If Black plays 5...dxc4 instead, White will recapture with 6.Qxc4. David Vigorito, Play the Semi-Slav, Quality Chess, 2008 ISBN 978-91-85779-01-7Authority control databases InternationalFASTNationalSpainGermanyIsraelUnited StatesRetr.  pawn. chess.
D41: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5. 3...Bb4 (the Accelerated Ragozin) intends to transpose to the Semi-Slav after 4...Nf6. 3...a6 (the Janowski Variation) threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense (from the white point of view) and the Exchange Variation. The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4. The Semi-Slav Defense occurs after black plays 4...c6 in the Three Knights Variation. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. Peter Leko, usually an e4 player, used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match.

Although White's pawn on h5 looks ready to attack, it can prove a weakness in an endgame. B10: The Caro-Kann Defense is known above all for its solidity. The defining move, 1...c6, is the fourth most popular reply to 1.e4. Black almost always captures with 3...dxe4, with White making the obvious reply 4...Nxe4. The Caro-Kann is named for Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, two 19th century players. At the 1927 New York tournament, world champion Jose Raul Capablanca used it as his main weapon against 1.e4. In his 1958 rematch with GM Vassily Smyslov, GM Mikhail Botvinnik became the first player to use it in a match for the world championship. The Caro–Kann has a reputation of being solid but somewhat boring. Black makes very few compromises in pawn structure and plays a timely ...c6–c5 to contest the d4-square. More popular recently are variations with Black castling kingside and even leaving his king in the centre. These variations can be sharp and dynamic. Viktor Korchnoi played 5...exf6 many times (including his first world championship match with Anatoly Karpov), and this line has also been employed by Ulf Andersson. The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. The Advance Variation has since been revitalized by aggressive lines such as the Bayonet Attack. The Panov–Botvinnik Attack begins with the move 4.c4. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3, somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. Black's logical and probably best reply is 3...Bg4. Karpov/Steinitz Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 dxe4 4.Nxe4 Nf6 5.Nxf6+ exf6 6.Bc4Milner–Barry Gambit, Rasa-Studier Gambit:1.e3 c3 2. d3 3. Nc3 4. Nxe4 5. Bf5 6.h4 h6 7.Nf3 Nd7 8.h5 Bh5 9.Bxd3 10.Qe2 Nb6.

B87: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov are two of the most famous players to have played the Sicilian. The Sicilian is the most played and most analysed opening at both the club and master levels. It fell out of favour when some of the world's leading players rejected it. The most frequent continuation is 3...Nf6 4.Be2, when 4...Nxe4? loses to 5.Qa4+ and likewise 4 ...Nc4?: loses to 6 d5 and 7a4+. 2.d3 signals White's intention to develop along King's Indian Attack lines, and usually transposes to the Closed Sicilian. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.Nf3. The drawback of 2.e5 is that no additional pressure is brought to the centre. The Sicilian Defence has more codes than any other opening. The Wing Gambit is generally considered too reckless, and rarely seen in grandmaster praxis. GM Joe Gallagher calls it "a forgotten relic, hardly having set foot in a tournament hall since ... well, not a lot"  c3 Sicilian is popular. Players usually enter the Grand Prix Attack by playing 2Nc4 before 3f3 or 3f4.
D25: The Queen's Gambit Accepted is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 dxc4. It is the third most popular option on Black's second move, after 2...e6 and 2...c6 (the Slav Defense) Black usually allows the pawn to be recaptured and uses the time expended to play against White's centre. 3.e4 is an old move that became popular again in the 1990s. The Alekhine Variation focuses on rapid development of pieces along with domination of the centre. 3.e3 prepares immediate recovery of the pawn and has often been employed by strong players, including Anatoly Karpov. 3. Nc3 was recommended by Keene and Jacobs in their opening repertoire for White. The queen check by 3.Qa4+ Nc6 4.Nf3 will quickly regain the pawn with Qxc4. 3...e5, 3...Nf6, and 3...a6 are all reasonable replies.

B80: The Sicilian Defence was analysed by Giulio Polerio in his 1594 manuscript on chess. It is used by world champions Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov. Black's most common move after 2.Nf3 is ...Nf6, followed by 2...e6. The immediate 5...e5?! is met by 6.Bb5+!, when Black must either play 6...Bd7 or 6...Nbd7. White's idea is to play f3, Qd2, 0-0-0 and g4 in some order. Black has three main moves: 4...Nc6 (the Taimanov Variation), 4...a6 ( the Kan Variation) and 4...E5. Black sometimes plays 3...e4 to avoid both moves; then 4...Bc4 is considered best. 2...Nc6 is the most common choice, but 2...e6 and 2...d6 are often played. Main line of the Closed Sicilian is 2.Nc3 Nc6 3.g3 g6 4.Bg2 Bg7 5.d3 d6 (diagram) Black's best reply is 2...exd5 3.5! Nf6!, the Talbit Gambit, which has caused 2f4 to decline in popularity. White can play the positional 5.Bb5, threatening to double Black's pawns. The modern main line runs 2. nc2 Nc2 3. f4 g4 4.f4 g6 5.Nf3 Bg3.

D14: The Slav Defense is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. It was analyzed as early as 1590, but not explored extensively until the 1920s. Many masters of Slavic descent helped develop the theory of this opening, including Alapin, Alekhine and Bogoljubov. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also try the following alternatives:4.Qc2 or 4.Qb3. Another way to play is 4...Bg4. White's sharpest try against 4...dxc4 is the Slav Geller Gambit, 5.e4. With 5.a4, White acts against ...b5 and prepares 6.e 4 and 7.Bxc4. Black's main move is 5...Bf5.

B45: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. In 1813, the English master Jacob Henry Sarratt effectively standardised his English translation of the name of this opening as 'the Sicilian defence' The Sicilian was fairly popular for much of the nineteenth century; Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais, Adolf Anderssen, Howard Staunton, Louis Paulsen, and Carl Jaenisch all played it with some consistency. It fell out of favour in the later part of the 19th century, when some of the world's leading players rejected it. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov popularised it in the 1980s and 1990s. 2.Na3 is an eccentric move recently returned to prominence by GM Vadim Zvjaginsev. Modern players would consider the notion that the Sicilian "prevents every attack" naive. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. 2.e5 gains space and prevents Black playing ...Nf6. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.nf3. The Tal Gambit Declined Archived 2012-06-24 at t at t.co.uk. The Grand International Masters' Tournament at St. Petersburg 1914, David McKay, c. 1915, p. 75.
D13: The Slav is one of the primary defenses to the Queen's Gambit. It was analyzed as early as 1590, but not explored extensively until the 1920s. Many masters of Slavic descent helped develop the theory of this opening, including Alapin, Alekhine and Bogoljubov. After 3...Nf6, the main line is 4.Nc3. Black can try the Winawer Countergambit, 3...e5, which was introduced in Marshall–Winawer, Monte Carlo 1901 but this is thought to be slightly better for White. White can also try the following alternatives. 5.e3 is a solid choice known as the Alekhine Variation. Play can proceed 5...b5 6.a4 b47.Na2 e6 8.Bxc47.Nb1 Ba6 9.bxc3 Bxf1 10.Nxf1 bxc3. Black's main move is 5...Bf5.
B11: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. The opening is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886.  Classical Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 dxe4 4.Nxe4 Nd7 5. Ng3 Bg6 6. h4 h6 7. Nf3 Nd 7 8. h5 Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10. Qxd3 e6 (10...Qc7 avoids White's next) 11. Bf4 Bb4+ 12. c3 Be7 13. 0-0-0 Ngf6 14. Kb1 0-1 15. Ne5 c5?! (15...Qa5 is usual and better) 16. Qf3 Qb6? (necessary was 16...cxd4 17.Rxd4 Nxe5 18.Bxe5 Qc8 19.Rhd1 Rd8 20.Ne4 with a small White advantage) 17. Nxd7 Nxc7 18. d The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop on g7, creating pressure against White's d4-pawn. After 4.Nf3 Bg7 White usually plays 5.h3 to prevent the ...Bg4 pin. Black's 5...exf6 is regarded as sounder than 5...gxf6!? and offers Black rapid development. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3 somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. The Hillbilly Attack is most often played by weaker players unfamiliar with the Caro–Kann Defence. Black may play 2...e5, the Open Variation (see 1.e4 c6 2.c4 e5). The 2...c4 line can also arise by transposition from the English Opening. Bronstein–Larsen Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 4.e5 Bg7 5.f4 h5Campomanes Attack:1.e3 Nc3 Nf6B16 – Bronstein-Larses Variation.
D47: The Semi-Slav Defense is a variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined chess opening. It is defined by the position reached after the moves:1. d4 d52. c4 c63. Nf3 Nf64. Nc3 e6. After the move order 1.d4 d5 2.c4 c6 3.Nc3 Black has the opportunity to respond with 3...e6 instead of 3...Nf6. This "triangle setup" opens up some new alternatives for both players on the fourth move. White has the option to enter the Marshall Gambit by playing 4.e4. The Meran is a chess variation first played in 1906 in Schlechter–Perlis. The variation takes its name from the town of Meran (Merano) in northern Italy. White will play in the center, leading to a rich, complicated game. Black's main plan, on the other hand, is to find a way to push ...c6–c5. According to some sources, the move was first played in 1923. The move 8...Bb7 was long considered virtually unplayable due to the line 9.e4 b4 10.Na4 c5 11.e5 Nd5 12.Nxc5 Nxc5 13.dxc5 Bxc5 14.Bb5+ and the black king will be stuck in the center. Continuing the game with 9.e4 b4 10.Na4 c5 11.e5 Nd5 is still very much an option for White. Instead of captures on c5, White can play 12.0-0 with some attacking prospects. The most critical continuation is 12...cxd4, after which White can either play 13.Re1 or 13.Nxd4. White can immediately push 11.e4, and Black must respond with the thematic 11...e5. Play often continues 12.dxe5 Nxe5 13.Nxe5 Bxe5 14.h3 with some slight advantage for White. After 11...h6 12.Nge4 Be7 the position seems very equal, though. The Moscow Variation 5...h6 6.Bxf6 Qxf6 gives rise to play of a very different character from the Botvinnik or Anti-Moscow Variations. Black aims to benefit from the slight dark square weaknesses left behind on the queenside after the bishop has moved outside the pawn chain. The Botvinnik Variation is probably one of the most complicated of all chess openings, with theory stretching past move thirty in some variations. The opening was introduced by Mikhail BotVinnik in the 1945 USSR vs. USA radio match vs. Arnold Denker. 11...Bb7 12.Bg2 Qb6 13.exf6 0-0-0 c5 (14...Ne5 is also an option): White can simply capture 15.dxe5, and while Black wins the queen after 15...Rxd1 16.Raxd1, white seems to have the upper hand at least according to engines. 16...Qa6 leads to another wild and forcing continuation: 17.a3 Bxd5 18.Bxd5 Ne5 19.axb4 Rxd5 20.Qe2 cxb4 21.Nc3. After 5.g3, White makes a claim that he's ready to play the Catalan, with the black pawn a bit passively on c6. This practically forces Black to take the c-pawn with 5...dxc4. After 7.Qb3, the game might continue 7...Nbd7 8.Bg5 Be7 9.e3 with equal opportunities. Black's best reply is considered to be 7...a6 8.e4 c5 and Black is supposed to be fine after either 9.dxc5 or 9. e5.
D40: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5. In the Orthodox Line, Black will often aim for the pawn break ...c5 in this opening. 3...a6 (the Janowski Variation) gained some interest in 2021 after being adopted by World Champion Magnus Carlsen. The move threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. White has alternatives to 4.Nf3 such as the Marshall Gambit 4.e4. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense (from the white point of view) The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5. Peter Leko used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match.

D82: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4. If White does not take the d5-pawn, Black may eventually play ...dxc4, when a White response of e4 again leads to the same pawn structure. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school of chess held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of  development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, however, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the exchange with White. The Grünfeld Gambit is not often met in top-flight play today, its usage having declined significantly since its heyday in the 1930s. Despite its reputation, in statistical databases this variation shows only a slightly higher percentage of White wins and draws, as opposed to the Exchange Variation. Chessgames: Neo-Grünfeld 3.f3 is a 3.g3 version of the classic chess game. The game is played with the rules of the 3. f3 version. It is available in English and German.

Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov popularised it in the 1980s and 1990s. 2.Na3 is an eccentric move recently returned to prominence by GM Vadim Zvjaginsev. Modern players would consider the notion that the Sicilian "prevents every attack" naive. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. 2.e5 gains space and prevents Black playing ...Nf6. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.nf3. The Tal Gambit Declined Archived 2012-06-24 at t at t.co.uk. The Grand International Masters' Tournament at St. Petersburg 1914, David McKay, c. 1915, p. 75.
B18: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. The opening is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886.  Classical Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 dxe4 4.Nxe4 Nd7 5. Ng3 Bg6 6. h4 h6 7. Nf3 Nd 7 8. h5 Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10. Qxd3 e6 (10...Qc7 avoids White's next) 11. Bf4 Bb4+ 12. c3 Be7 13. 0-0-0 Ngf6 14. Kb1 0-1 15. Ne5 c5?! (15...Qa5 is usual and better) 16. Qf3 Qb6? (necessary was 16...cxd4 17.Rxd4 Nxe5 18.Bxe5 Qc8 19.Rhd1 Rd8 20.Ne4 with a small White advantage) 17. Nxd7 Nxc7 18. d The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop on g7, creating pressure against White's d4-pawn. After 4.Nf3 Bg7 White usually plays 5.h3 to prevent the ...Bg4 pin. Black's 5...exf6 is regarded as sounder than 5...gxf6!? and offers Black rapid development. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3 somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. The Hillbilly Attack is most often played by weaker players unfamiliar with the Caro–Kann Defence. Black may play 2...e5, the Open Variation (see 1.e4 c6 2.c4 e5). The 2...c4 line can also arise by transposition from the English Opening. Bronstein–Larsen Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 4.e5 Bg7 5.f4 h5Campomanes Attack:1.e3 Nc3 Nf6B16 – Bronstein-Larses Variation.
A58: The Benko Gambit (or Volga Gambit) is a chess opening characterised by the move 3...b5 in the Benoni Defence. Black sacrifices a pawn for enduring queenside pressure. The idea of sacrificing a pawn with ...b5 and ...a6 is quite old. In many countries, particularly in Eastern Europe, the opening is known as the Volgas Gambit. The Pal Benko Gambit is one of the most popular openings in chess. It is named after the eponym, Pal Benco, who was a chess player in the 19th century. The gambit can be played in a number of ways, including 4...bxc4.
A67: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6
C55: The Italian Game is a family of chess openings beginning with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4ECOC50–C59Origin15th or 16th centuryParentKing's Knight Opening. Black's two main options are 3...Bc5 and 3...Nf6. 3...g6. Allows White to attack with 4.d4 (4.d3 has also been tried) 4...exd4 5.c3! (5.Nxd4 and 5.Bg5 are also possible) 5...dxc3 6.Nxc3 Bg7 and now 7.Qb3 (Unzicker) or 7. Bg5 (O'Kelly) 3...Nd4 is a false gambit expectant upon White falling into the trap of capturing Black's undefended pawn. 3...h6. Neglects Black's development and is generally considered a waste of time.
E03: The Catalan Opening is a chess opening where White plays d4 and c4 and fianchettoes the white bishop on g2. In the Catalan, White adopts a combination of the Queen's Gambit and Réti Opening. Vladimir Kramnik, Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen all employing the opening in their World Chess Championship title games. Kramnik vs. Anand, Wijk aan Zee 2007 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.g3 d5 4.Bg2 Be7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.0-0 dxc4 7.Qc2 a6 8.Qxc4 b5 9.Bb7 10.Bd2 Ra7 11.Rc1 Be4 12.Qb3 Nc6 13.e3 Qa8 14.Qd1 Nb8 15.Ba5 Rc8 16.a3 Bd6 17.Nbd2 Bd5 18.Qf1 Nbd7 19.b4 e5 20.dxe5 Bxe5 21.Nxe5 Nxe5 22.f3 N c4 23.Nxc4 Bxc4 24.QF2 Re8 25.e4 c6 26.Rd
A93: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines. A94: 1.d4 f5 2.c4 Nf6 3.g3 e6 4.Bg2 Be7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.0-0 d5 7.b3 c6 8.Ba3 (Stonewall)
C99: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.

E32: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)

A51: The Budapest Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e5. The first known game with the gambit is Adler–Maróczy (played in Budapest in 1896) It enjoyed a rise in popularity in the early 1920s, but nowadays is rarely played at the top level. The "Budapest rook" is a manoeuvre, introduced by the IM Dolfi Drimer in 1968. In most variations Black has the opportunity to play Bb4+, a move whose advisability depends on White's possible answers. White can try to exploit weaknesses with the manoeuvres Bf4–d2–c3 (pressure along the diagonal a1–h8), Ng1–e2–g3–h5 and h2–h4. Budapest Gambit is one of the most famous openings in chess. It involves pawn advances on the queenside, resulting in the creation of a weak pawn for Black, then winning this weak pawn. Alekhine considers 7.Nc3! to be the best system against the Budapest Gambit. The Budapest gambit was referenced in season 28, episode 15, of The Simpsons, in an episode called "The Cad and the Hat" Black mates with either 31.Kf5 g6+ or 32.KF6 Bd4 mate,  or 31. Kf5g6+ g6+. Black mate with either 32. KF6 g4+ or 32. kf6 g5+.

E61: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken, now reared either for meat or show. It originated in the early nineteenth century in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast; the eggs are brown. In the early twentieth century the name was changed in the United States to Cornish.
A05: The King's Indian Attack (KIA) is a chess opening system where White adopts the setup more commonly seen being played by Black. The KIA is a closed, strategic opening that presents its practitioner with common themes and tactics and a comfortable middlegame against various defences. After 1.e4 e6, the game might typically proceed as follows: 4.Ngf3 Nf6 5.g3 Nc6 6.Bg2 Be7 7.0-0 0-0 8.Re1 (see diagram in previous section) White will now look to play e4–e5, cramping Black, and then proceed with moves such as Nf1, Bf4, Qe2, h4, N1h2 (or Ne3), h5, g4 (or Ng4) Maddox, Don (2002): Königsindischer Angriff - Schach Training, Hamburg: ChessBase GmbH, ISBN 3-935602-51-0New In Chess Yearbook (1998): King's Indian Attack: Black castles kingside, Alkmaar: Interchess BV, Vol. 49, ISBN  90-5691-044-2, p. 186-190.Norwood, David (1991): King’s Indian Attack, London: Trends Publications, without ISBNSchiller, Eric (1989): How To Play The Kings Indian attack, Moon Township: Chess Enterprises, ISBN 0-931462-95-9.Tangborn, Eric: A Fischer Favorite: The King'sIndian Attack – with 46 fully annotated Games, o.O.: International Chess Enterprises.
C08: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
E92: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. A02: Bird's Opening (or the Dutch Attack) is a chess opening characterised by the move:1.f4ECOA02–A03Named after 19th century English player Henry Bird, Bird's opening is a standard flank opening. White's strategic ideas involve control of the e5-square, offering good attacking chances at the expense of slightly weakening their own kingside. Emanuel Lasker introduced 4...g5 in the game Bird–Lasker, Newcastle upon Tyne, 1892. International Master (IM) Timothy Taylor, in his 2005 book on the Bird's, recommends 3.Nc3! Nxe5 4.d4 intending 5.e4, rather than 3.nf3?! g5! when Black stands well. The offbeat 1...b6!? is also known, and more soundly based than the same move after 1.e4 or 1.d4. Black may build up more slowly with 2.Nf3, followed by g3, Bg2, d3, and possibly a later e4. Out of the twenty possible opening moves, 1.f4 ranks sixth in popularity in Chessgames.com's database. It is less than one-twentieth as popular as the mirror image English Opening (1.c4).[15] The move slightly weakens White's king's position. White scores much better with the more popular 1.e4 (54.25%), 1.d4 (55.95%) and 1.Nf3 ( 55.8%) Ponziani OpeningRuy LopezSemi-Italian OpeningScotch GameTwo Knights DefenseVienna GameOwen's DefencePirc DefenceAustrian AttackScandinavian DefenseSicilian DefenceAlapinDragon/Accelerated DragonNajdorfScheveningenQueen's Pawn GameBudapest GambitColle SystemDutch DefenceEnglish DefenceIndian DefenceBenoni DefenceModern BenoniBogo-Indian DefenceCatalan OpeningGrünfeld DefenceKing's Indian DefenceNimzo-Indian DefenseOld Indian DefenseQueen's Indian DefenseLondon SystemRichter–Veresov AttackQueen's GambitAcceptedDeclined.
C30: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.f4ECOC30–C39Origin no later than 16th centuryParentOpen Game. White offers a pawn to divert the black e-pawn. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4. After 2...exf4, the two main continuations for White are 3.Nf3 (King's Knight's Gambit) and 3.Bc4 (Bishop'sGambit) Black's two main approaches are to attempt to hold on to the pawn with ...g5, or to return the pawn in order to facilitate development. With 4.h4 White practically forces 4...g4, thereby undermining any attempt by Black to set up a stable pawn chain. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. The move has received renewed attention following its recommendation by John Shaw in his 2013 book on the King's Gambit. The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6), although previously known, was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. Fischer's analysis of 3...d6, which he called "a high-class waiting move", was published in the American Chess Quarterly in 1960. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. 2...Nc6, advocated by Tony Miles; 2...d6, which is the way the King’s Gambit was declined the first known time it was played. The greedy 2...Qf6 (known as the Nordwalde Variation), intending 3...Qxf4, is considered dubious. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings has ten codes for the King's Gambit, C30 through C39.

E59: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)

A34: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C06: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.

C96: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.

There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)
C62: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.
A50: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken, now reared either for meat or show. It originated in the early nineteenth century in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast; the eggs are brown. In the early twentieth century the name was changed in the United States to Cornish.
A68: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6
A57: The Benko Gambit (or Volga Gambit) is a chess opening characterised by the move 3...b5 in the Benoni Defence. Black sacrifices a pawn for enduring queenside pressure. The idea of sacrificing a pawn with ...b5 and ...a6 is quite old. In many countries, particularly in Eastern Europe, the opening is known as the Volgas Gambit. The Pal Benko Gambit is one of the most popular openings in chess. It is named after the eponym, Pal Benco, who was a chess player in the 19th century. The gambit can be played in a number of ways, including 4...bxc4.

A95: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines. A32: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C00: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.

E69: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)
C07: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
A35: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C38: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.f4ECOC30–C39Origin no later than 16th centuryParentOpen Game. White offers a pawn to divert the black e-pawn. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4. After 2...exf4, the two main continuations for White are 3.Nf3 (King's Knight's Gambit) and 3.Bc4 (Bishop'sGambit) Black's two main approaches are to attempt to hold on to the pawn with ...g5, or to return the pawn in order to facilitate development. With 4.h4 White practically forces 4...g4, thereby undermining any attempt by Black to set up a stable pawn chain. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. The move has received renewed attention following its recommendation by John Shaw in his 2013 book on the King's Gambit. The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6), although previously known, was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. Fischer's analysis of 3...d6, which he called "a high-class waiting move", was published in the American Chess Quarterly in 1960. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. 2...Nc6, advocated by Tony Miles; 2...d6, which is the way the King’s Gambit was declined the first known time it was played. The greedy 2...Qf6 (known as the Nordwalde Variation), intending 3...Qxf4, is considered dubious. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings has ten codes for the King's Gambit, C30 through C39.

A03: Bird's Opening (or the Dutch Attack) is a chess opening characterised by the move:1.f4ECOA02–A03Named after 19th century English player Henry Bird, Bird's opening is a standard flank opening. White's strategic ideas involve control of the e5-square, offering good attacking chances at the expense of slightly weakening their own kingside. Emanuel Lasker introduced 4...g5 in the game Bird–Lasker, Newcastle upon Tyne, 1892. International Master (IM) Timothy Taylor, in his 2005 book on the Bird's, recommends 3.Nc3! Nxe5 4.d4 intending 5.e4, rather than 3.nf3?! g5! when Black stands well. The offbeat 1...b6!? is also known, and more soundly based than the same move after 1.e4 or 1.d4. Black may build up more slowly with 2.Nf3, followed by g3, Bg2, d3, and possibly a later e4. Out of the twenty possible opening moves, 1.f4 ranks sixth in popularity in Chessgames.com's database. It is less than one-twentieth as popular as the mirror image English Opening (1.c4).[15] The move slightly weakens White's king's position. White scores much better with the more popular 1.e4 (54.25%), 1.d4 (55.95%) and 1.Nf3 ( 55.8%) Ponziani OpeningRuy LopezSemi-Italian OpeningScotch GameTwo Knights DefenseVienna GameOwen's DefencePirc DefenceAustrian AttackScandinavian DefenseSicilian DefenceAlapinDragon/Accelerated DragonNajdorfScheveningenQueen's Pawn GameBudapest GambitColle SystemDutch DefenceEnglish DefenceIndian DefenceBenoni DefenceModern BenoniBogo-Indian DefenceCatalan OpeningGrünfeld DefenceKing's Indian DefenceNimzo-Indian DefenseOld Indian DefenseQueen's Indian DefenseLondon SystemRichter–Veresov AttackQueen's GambitAcceptedDeclined.
E67: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. E60: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken, now reared either for meat or show. It originated in the early nineteenth century in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast; the eggs are brown. In the early twentieth century the name was changed in the United States to Cornish.
A04: The Sokolsky Opening is an uncommon chess opening that begins with the move:1. b4. Out of the twenty possible first moves from White, the move 1.b4 ranks ninth in popularity. It is considered an irregular opening, so it is classified under the A00 code in the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings. The opening is largely based upon tactics on the queenside or the f6- and g7-squares. After 1...a5 White will most likely play 2.b5 and take advantage of Black's queenside weakness. Black's 1...c5 is much sharper and more aggressive and is normally used to avoid theory. Black will generally place pressure on the c5-square and will develop an attack against White's weak queenside structure.

Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.

E42: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)

C25: The Vienna Game is an opening in chess that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nc3ECOC25–C29. The original idea behind the Vienna Game was to play a delayed King's Gambit with f4 (the Vienna Gambit) 3.g3, the Mieses Variation, is a quiet continuation in which White fianchettoes his king's bishop, a line played by Vasily Smyslov on a few occasions, most notably in a win over Lev Polugaevsky in the 1961 USSR Championship. After 4...Ng4, White may also play improved versions of the Ulvestad Variation (6.b4 in the above line) and Fritz Variation. The Hamppe–Muzio Gambit is characterised by the continuation 3...exf4 4.Nf3 g5 5.Bc4 g4 6.0-0 gxf3 7.Qxf3 (see diagram) The Steinitz Gambit was a favorite of Wilhelm Steinitz, the first World Champion. The Dubois Variation continues 7...Ne5 8. Qxf4 Qf6. After 3.f4, ...d6 leads to the King's Gambit Declined. Weak is 3.Qg4 Nf6! 4.Qxg7 Rg8 5.Qh6 Bxf2+ when Black had a large advantage in Tsikhelashvili–Karpov, USSR 1968. Another offbeat possibility is 3...Na4, the Hamppe Variation.
E73: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. C22: The Center Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.d4 exd4. The game usually continues 3.Qxd4 Nc6, developing with a gain of tempo for Black due to the attack on the white queen. (Note that 3.c3 is considered a separate opening: the Danish Gambit.)

C82: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f.
