C04: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.

E99: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. C03: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
A31: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. E55: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)

C35: The King's Gambit is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.f4ECOC30–C39Origin no later than 16th centuryParentOpen Game. White offers a pawn to divert the black e-pawn. If Black accepts the gambit, White may play d4 and Bxf4. After 2...exf4, the two main continuations for White are 3.Nf3 (King's Knight's Gambit) and 3.Bc4 (Bishop'sGambit) Black's two main approaches are to attempt to hold on to the pawn with ...g5, or to return the pawn in order to facilitate development. With 4.h4 White practically forces 4...g4, thereby undermining any attempt by Black to set up a stable pawn chain. The Quaade Gambit (3.Nf3 g5 4.Nc3) is named after a Danish amateur who discussed it in correspondence with the Deutsche Schachzeitung in the 1880s. The move has received renewed attention following its recommendation by John Shaw in his 2013 book on the King's Gambit. The Fischer Defense (3.Nf3 d6), although previously known, was advocated by Bobby Fischer after he was defeated by Boris Spassky in a Kieseritzky Gambit at the 1960 Mar del Plata tournament. Fischer's analysis of 3...d6, which he called "a high-class waiting move", was published in the American Chess Quarterly in 1960. Black's other main option is 3...d5, returning the pawn immediately. John Shaw wrote that 3...Nc6 is a "refutation" of the Bishop's Gambit. The Falkbeer Countergambit is named after the 19th-century Austrian master Ernst Falkbeer. 2...Nc6, advocated by Tony Miles; 2...d6, which is the way the King’s Gambit was declined the first known time it was played. The greedy 2...Qf6 (known as the Nordwalde Variation), intending 3...Qxf4, is considered dubious. The Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings has ten codes for the King's Gambit, C30 through C39.
A07: The King's Indian Attack (KIA) is a chess opening system where White adopts the setup more commonly seen being played by Black. The KIA is a closed, strategic opening that presents its practitioner with common themes and tactics and a comfortable middlegame against various defences. After 1.e4 e6, the game might typically proceed as follows: 4.Ngf3 Nf6 5.g3 Nc6 6.Bg2 Be7 7.0-0 0-0 8.Re1 (see diagram in previous section) White will now look to play e4–e5, cramping Black, and then proceed with moves such as Nf1, Bf4, Qe2, h4, N1h2 (or Ne3), h5, g4 (or Ng4) Maddox, Don (2002): Königsindischer Angriff - Schach Training, Hamburg: ChessBase GmbH, ISBN 3-935602-51-0New In Chess Yearbook (1998): King's Indian Attack: Black castles kingside, Alkmaar: Interchess BV, Vol. 49, ISBN  90-5691-044-2, p. 186-190.Norwood, David (1991): King’s Indian Attack, London: Trends Publications, without ISBNSchiller, Eric (1989): How To Play The Kings Indian attack, Moon Township: Chess Enterprises, ISBN 0-931462-95-9.Tangborn, Eric: A Fischer Favorite: The King'sIndian Attack – with 46 fully annotated Games, o.O.: International Chess Enterprises.

A00: Anderssen's Opening is named after unofficial World Chess Champion Adolf Anderssen, who played it three times in his 1858 match against Paul Morphy. Although Anderssen was defeated decisively in the match, the games he opened with the novelty scored 1½/3 (one win, one loss, one draw). The move is not commonly played, and is an irregular opening. Anderssen's Opening (ECO A00) 1.a3 e5 2.c4 Nf6 3.c3 d5 4.cxd5 Nxd5 5.e3 Be6 6.Nf3 Bd6 7.Be2 O-O 8.d4 Nxc3 9.bxc3 e4 10.Nd2 f5 11.f4 Qh4+ 12.g3 Qh3 13.Bf1 Qh6 14c4 c6 15.c5 Bc7 16.Bc4 nd7 17.O-O b5 18.cxb6 axb6 19.Qb3 Rfe8 20.Bb2 b5 21.Bxe6+ Qxe6 22.Qc2 Qd5 23.Rfc1 Ra6 24.a4 Rea8 25.axb5 Qxb5 26. Chess tournaments include the Chess Olympiad, Chess World Cup, and Chess Grand Prix. Chess is a game of strategy, strategy, and strategy. C59: The Italian Game is a family of chess openings beginning with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4ECOC50–C59Origin15th or 16th centuryParentKing's Knight Opening. Black's two main options are 3...Bc5 and 3...Nf6. 3...g6. Allows White to attack with 4.d4 (4.d3 has also been tried) 4...exd4 5.c3! (5.Nxd4 and 5.Bg5 are also possible) 5...dxc3 6.Nxc3 Bg7 and now 7.Qb3 (Unzicker) or 7. Bg5 (O'Kelly) 3...Nd4 is a false gambit expectant upon White falling into the trap of capturing Black's undefended pawn. 3...h6. Neglects Black's development and is generally considered a waste of time.
C66: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.

C92: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.
A98: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines. A94: 1.d4 f5 2.c4 Nf6 3.g3 e6 4.Bg2 Be7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.0-0 d5 7.b3 c6 8.Ba3 (Stonewall)

Vladimir Kramnik, Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen all employing the opening in their World Chess Championship title games. E37: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. A65: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6
C57: The Italian Game is a family of chess openings beginning with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4ECOC50–C59Origin15th or 16th centuryParentKing's Knight Opening. Black's two main options are 3...Bc5 and 3...Nf6. 3...g6. Allows White to attack with 4.d4 (4.d3 has also been tried) 4...exd4 5.c3! (5.Nxd4 and 5.Bg5 are also possible) 5...dxc3 6.Nxc3 Bg7 and now 7.Qb3 (Unzicker) or 7. Bg5 (O'Kelly) 3...Nd4 is a false gambit expectant upon White falling into the trap of capturing Black's undefended pawn. 3...h6. Neglects Black's development and is generally considered a waste of time.

A40: The Caro–Kann Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 (or 3.d2) 4.Nxe4 Bf5. The opening is named after Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann, both of whom analysed it in 1886.  Classical Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 dxe4 4.Nxe4 Nd7 5. Ng3 Bg6 6. h4 h6 7. Nf3 Nd 7 8. h5 Bh7 9. Bd3 Bxd3 10. Qxd3 e6 (10...Qc7 avoids White's next) 11. Bf4 Bb4+ 12. c3 Be7 13. 0-0-0 Ngf6 14. Kb1 0-1 15. Ne5 c5?! (15...Qa5 is usual and better) 16. Qf3 Qb6? (necessary was 16...cxd4 17.Rxd4 Nxe5 18.Bxe5 Qc8 19.Rhd1 Rd8 20.Ne4 with a small White advantage) 17. Nxd7 Nxc7 18. d The Gurgenidze Variation is 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6. Black prepares to fianchetto the bishop on g7, creating pressure against White's d4-pawn. After 4.Nf3 Bg7 White usually plays 5.h3 to prevent the ...Bg4 pin. Black's 5...exf6 is regarded as sounder than 5...gxf6!? and offers Black rapid development. The Fantasy Variation, formerly known as the Tartakower or Maroçzy variation, 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.f3 somewhat resembles the Blackmar–Diemer Gambit. The Two Knights Variation was played by Bobby Fischer in his youth, but has since declined in popularity. The Hillbilly Attack is most often played by weaker players unfamiliar with the Caro–Kann Defence. Black may play 2...e5, the Open Variation (see 1.e4 c6 2.c4 e5). The 2...c4 line can also arise by transposition from the English Opening. Bronstein–Larsen Variation: 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.Nc3 g6 4.e5 Bg7 5.f4 h5Campomanes Attack:1.e3 Nc3 Nf6B16 – Bronstein-Larses Variation.

C75: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.
A78: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6
A85: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines. C43: The Petrov Defence is a symmetrical response to the King's Knight Opening. It was popularised by Alexander Petrov, a Russian chess player in the mid-19th century. The Petrov has a drawish reputation, but offers attacking opportunities for both sides. The Cochrane Gambit, 4.Nxf7, is labelled "speculative but entertaining" by Nick de Firmian in Modern Chess Openings (MCO) 14th edition. White must avoid 5...Bf5?? 6.Qe2! which wins a piece due to the pin (if 6...Qe7 7.Nd5, forcing 7...Qd7 because of the threat to the c7-pawn) Viswanathan Anand resigned after only six moves after falling for this against Alonso Zapata at Biel in 1988. 3.Nc3 is the Three Knights Game of Petrov's Defence. With 3...Nc6, it transposes to the Two Knights Defence. 3.Bc4 Nxe4 is the Boden–Kieseritzky Gambit. Black can accept the gambit with 4...Nxc3 5.dxc3 f6.

C44: The King's Pawn Game is any chess opening starting with the move:1.e4. It is the most popular opening move in chess, followed by the Queen's P pawn Game. Bobby Fischer said that the opening is "Best by test", and proclaimed that "With 1. e4! I win" 1...d6 is usually played with the intention of playing the Pirc Defence (1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6, ECO codes B07–B09), a hypermodern defence. It can also lead to the Modern Defence, Pribyl System or Philidor Defence. After 2...d4, there are two distinctive main lines: 2...e5, favoured by British grandmaster Tony Miles, and 2 ...d5, introduced by Latvian-Danish player and writer Aron Nimzowitsch. 1...Nh6 is considered a joke opening after 3.Qh5+. Black has to play g6 and ruin their kingside position. Another move in this position is 2...Kf7, dubbed the "Fred" It can transpose to the old hippo system. A49: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken, now reared either for meat or show. It originated in the early nineteenth century in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast; the eggs are brown. In the early twentieth century the name was changed in the United States to Cornish.
E79: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. C10: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
A22: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C28: The Bishop's Opening is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Bc4ECOC23–C24Named afterBishop in 2.bc4. White attacks Black's f7-square and prevents Black from advancing the d-pawn to d5. By ignoring the beginner's maxim "develop knights before bishops", White leaves their f-p pawn unblocked. The Boden–Kieseritzky Gambit is named after English players and chess writers Samuel Boden and Lionel Kieserizky. Black has a solid position with no clear weaknesses, but White has attacking chances and piece activity as compensation for the pawn. Black's lack of development and inability to castle kingside can prove very problematic. Black's most energetic response to the Philidor Variation is the Lewis Countergambit, 3.c3 d5, named for the English player and author William Lewis (1787–1870) who published analysis of the line in 1834. Other Black second moves are rarely played. If Black tries to transpose into the Hungarian Defense with 2...Be7?, then 3.Qh5 wins a pawn.

The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)
E48: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E83: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. A13: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C21: The Center Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.d4 exd4. The game usually continues 3.Qxd4 Nc6, developing with a gain of tempo for Black due to the attack on the white queen. (Note that 3.c3 is considered a separate opening: the Danish Gambit.)
C19: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
C26: The Bishop's Opening is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Bc4ECOC23–C24Named afterBishop in 2.bc4. White attacks Black's f7-square and prevents Black from advancing the d-pawn to d5. By ignoring the beginner's maxim "develop knights before bishops", White leaves their f-p pawn unblocked. The Boden–Kieseritzky Gambit is named after English players and chess writers Samuel Boden and Lionel Kieserizky. Black has a solid position with no clear weaknesses, but White has attacking chances and piece activity as compensation for the pawn. Black's lack of development and inability to castle kingside can prove very problematic. Black's most energetic response to the Philidor Variation is the Lewis Countergambit, 3.c3 d5, named for the English player and author William Lewis (1787–1870) who published analysis of the line in 1834. Other Black second moves are rarely played. If Black tries to transpose into the Hungarian Defense with 2...Be7?, then 3.Qh5 wins a pawn.

A83: The Dutch Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 f5. Black's 1...f5 stakes a claim to the e4-square and envisions an attack on White's kingside. The Dutch has never been a main line against 1.d4 and is rarely seen today in high-level competition. The Staunton Gambit was once a feared attacking line, but it has been out of favour for over 80 years. Carl Mayet introduced a completely different gambit approach to the Dutch in 1839, playing 2.h3 followed by 3.g4. Black sometimes starts with the move order 1...e6 to avoid these lines. A94: 1.d4 f5 2.c4 Nf6 3.g3 e6 4.Bg2 Be7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.0-0 d5 7.b3 c6 8.Ba3 (Stonewall)
E13: The opening is a solid defense to the Queen's Pawn Game. Black attempts to control the center with pieces in hypermodern style, instead of occupying it with pawns in classical style. The Queen's Indian is regarded as the sister opening of the Nimzo-Indian, since both openings aim to impede White's efforts to gain full control of the center. The classical main line of the Queen's Indian, the most frequently played line from the 1950s until 4...Ba6 became popular in the 1980s, usually continues. White has tried various deviations from the main line in an attempt to unbalance the play. These include:8. Bd2, which defends the knight on c3 and threatens a d4–d5 push. E13 – 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 b6 4.Nc3 Bb7 5.Bg2 Be7 6.0-0 0-0 7. Nc3 Ne4 8.Qc2
C45: The Scotch Game is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4ECOC44–C45Origin1750Named afterScotlandParentKing's Knight OpeningSynonym(s)Scotch Opening. After 1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 exd4, the most important continuations are:4.Nxd4 (Main line)4...Bc5 (Classical Variation) 4...Nf6 (Schmidt Variation), 4...Qh4!? (Steinitz Variation). White can play a gambit by offering Black one or two pawns in exchange for rapid development. As of 2005, White's most successful line has been 5.Nb3 Bb2 Qe2, Be3 or Bg5. 4.c3, dubbed the Haxo Gambit by Eric Schiller, has little independent significance. After 4.Bc4, Black can transpose into the 4.d4 exd4 line of the Two Knights Defence with 4...Nf6, or continue 4...Bc5. Black can instead accept the gambit with 5...dxc3, but this is riskier because White will gain a lead in development. Black can also decline with 4...Nf6, transposing to a line of the Ponziani Opening. White can deviate with 6...Bg4 7.Nc3, with the idea of meeting 7...Bb4 with 8.a3. Black's most critical response is generally considered to be 5...Nd5. After 5...d6, White's best is 6.Nxc3, transposing back to the 5.Nc3 Nf6 line. 5...Bb4 is well met by 6.0-0 or 6.bxc3 (transposing to the Scotch Gambit) 6...Bc5 also transposes to the Scottish Gambit.
A77: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6
A48: The Indian Game is a British breed of game chicken, now reared either for meat or show. It originated in the early nineteenth century in the counties of Cornwall and Devon in south-west England. It is a heavy, muscular bird with an unusually broad breast; the eggs are brown. In the early twentieth century the name was changed in the United States to Cornish.

C42: The Petrov Defence is a symmetrical response to the King's Knight Opening. It was popularised by Alexander Petrov, a Russian chess player in the mid-19th century. The Petrov has a drawish reputation, but offers attacking opportunities for both sides. The Cochrane Gambit, 4.Nxf7, is labelled "speculative but entertaining" by Nick de Firmian in Modern Chess Openings (MCO) 14th edition. White must avoid 5...Bf5?? 6.Qe2! which wins a piece due to the pin (if 6...Qe7 7.Nd5, forcing 7...Qd7 because of the threat to the c7-pawn) Viswanathan Anand resigned after only six moves after falling for this against Alonso Zapata at Biel in 1988. 3.Nc3 is the Three Knights Game of Petrov's Defence. With 3...Nc6, it transposes to the Two Knights Defence. 3.Bc4 Nxe4 is the Boden–Kieseritzky Gambit. Black can accept the gambit with 4...Nxc3 5.dxc3 f6.

C89: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. The Modern Arkhangelsk Defence (or Modern Archangel Defence) (ECO C78) is sometimes called the Neo-Arkhangelsk or Neo-Archangel. The name derives from White's play if Black captures the knight: 4...Nxe5 5.d4. An important alternative is 4.d3, dubbed the Anti-Berlin, which avoids the notorious Berlin endgame. Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.

Wilhelm Steinitz scored many spectacular successes with it during his reign as World Champion. Main replies for Black are 4...d6 and 4...Bc5, the la and 4 Bc4, the bc and bg and the c and d and the e and f. The line has been used by many players, with mixed results, to avoid the notorious endgame of 4...D6 and 4...D7. It has also been used as a way of avoiding the end game of 4 D4 and D5.
C80: The Ruy Lopez is named after 16th-century Spanish priest Ruy López de Segura. It is one of the most popular openings, with many variations. A common nickname for the opening is "The Spanish Torture" After 3...a6, the most commonly played line is the Closed Defence, which goes 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7. The Graz Defence, Classical Defence Deferred, and Møller Defence combine 3... a6 with the active move ...Bc5. In the Modern Steinitz Defence, Black is able to maintain control of the centre. A79: Benoni is an ancient Hebrew name, still occasionally used, meaning "son of my sorrow". It is a reference to the Biblical account of the dying Rachel giving birth to Benjamin, whom she named Ben-Oni. The name "Benoni" came to be associated with the opening 1.d4 c5. The Old Benoni Defense is sometimes called the Blackburn Defense after Englishman Joseph Henry Blackburne, the first player known to have used it. Benoni is more solid than the Modern Benoni, but also more passive. In most lines, Black will look to break with ...b7–b5 or ...f7–f5 after due preparation. Black sacrifices a pawn for open lines and long-term positional pressure on the queen's side. A65 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 c5 3.d5 e6 4.Nc3 exd5 5.cxd5 d6 6.e4 g6 7.f4 Bg7 8.Be2 0-0 9.0-0 Re8 10.Nd2 Na6

A41: The Modern Defense is a hypermodern chess opening in which Black allows White to occupy the center with pawns on d4 and e4. Black then proceeds to attack and undermine this "ideal" center without attempting to occupy it. The opening has been most notably used by British grandmasters Nigel Davies and Colin McNab. After 2.Nf3, Black can play 2...c5, transposing to the Sicilian Defense, or 2...Bg7. Black can transpose to a closed Sicilian  with 2... c5 or play 2 ...Bg6. The Averbakh system is reached after 2...b7.
E25: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)
C18: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
E85: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. A15: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C27: The Bishop's Opening is a chess opening that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Bc4ECOC23–C24Named afterBishop in 2.bc4. White attacks Black's f7-square and prevents Black from advancing the d-pawn to d5. By ignoring the beginner's maxim "develop knights before bishops", White leaves their f-p pawn unblocked. The Boden–Kieseritzky Gambit is named after English players and chess writers Samuel Boden and Lionel Kieserizky. Black has a solid position with no clear weaknesses, but White has attacking chances and piece activity as compensation for the pawn. Black's lack of development and inability to castle kingside can prove very problematic. Black's most energetic response to the Philidor Variation is the Lewis Countergambit, 3.c3 d5, named for the English player and author William Lewis (1787–1870) who published analysis of the line in 1834. Other Black second moves are rarely played. If Black tries to transpose into the Hungarian Defense with 2...Be7?, then 3.Qh5 wins a pawn.

C29: The Vienna Game is an opening in chess that begins with the moves:1.e4 e5 2.Nc3ECOC25–C29. The original idea behind the Vienna Game was to play a delayed King's Gambit with f4 (the Vienna Gambit) 3.g3, the Mieses Variation, is a quiet continuation in which White fianchettoes his king's bishop, a line played by Vasily Smyslov on a few occasions, most notably in a win over Lev Polugaevsky in the 1961 USSR Championship. After 4...Ng4, White may also play improved versions of the Ulvestad Variation (6.b4 in the above line) and Fritz Variation. The Hamppe–Muzio Gambit is characterised by the continuation 3...exf4 4.Nf3 g5 5.Bc4 g4 6.0-0 gxf3 7.Qxf3 (see diagram) The Steinitz Gambit was a favorite of Wilhelm Steinitz, the first World Champion. The Dubois Variation continues 7...Ne5 8. Qxf4 Qf6. After 3.f4, ...d6 leads to the King's Gambit Declined. Weak is 3.Qg4 Nf6! 4.Qxg7 Rg8 5.Qh6 Bxf2+ when Black had a large advantage in Tsikhelashvili–Karpov, USSR 1968. Another offbeat possibility is 3...Na4, the Hamppe Variation.

It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. E40: The Nimzo-Indian Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 e63. Nc3 Bb4. In the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings, it is classified as E20–E59. This hypermodern opening was developed by Aron Nimzowitsch. 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.Nf3 c5 7.0-0 4...Nc6 is the Taimanov Variation, named after Russian GM Mark Taimanovsky. The Larsen Variation (named after GM Bent Larsen) can be reached by either 7...dxc4 8.Bxc4 Nc6 9.a3 Bxc3 dxc4 10.bxc3 Qc7 (Main Variation) 7...Dxc4 (Karpov) 8. Bc6 (Bronstein) 8...Bd7 followed by ...Bc6  is the Bronstein Variation. There are several move orders to reach the Main Variation besides the one given above; 4.e3 0-0 5.Bd3 d5 6.a3 Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 dxc4 8.Bxc4 c5 9.Nf3 Nc6 10.0-0 is one worth noting, because White may try 9.Ne2 instead. In the Rubinstein, White has often resorted to playing Ne2 rather than Nf3 to be able to recapture on c3. 4.e3 c5 is one of the most popular moves in the game. There are two major variations particular to 4...c5: 5.Bd3 Nc6 6.Nf3 (6.Ne2 will likely transpose to the Modern Variation) 6...Bxc3+ 7.bxc3 d6 is the Hübner Variation, popularized by GM Robert HüBner in the late 1960s and '70s. The Classical Fianchetto Variation can be reached through two move orders: 4.e3 b6 5.Bd3 Bb7 6.Nf3 0-0 7.0-0 d5. The Keres Variation is named after Estonian GM Paul Keres, although Smyslov and Bronstein were also early practitioners of this line. The Capablanca Position was popular in the early days of the Nimzo Position. 4...0-0, 4...c5, 4 ...d5, and 4...Nc6 are common replies to 4.Qc2. Black can choose to recapture on c5 with the bishop (e.g. 5...Bxc5) or with the knight (after 5...Na6 or 6.Nf3 Na6) White almost always plays 5.dxc5. The Pirc Variation was not popular during the mid-20th century, because the lines where Black eventually recaptures with theKnight was reckoned to give Black easy equality. 4...Nc6 is the Zürich or Milner-Barry Variation. Black gives up the dark-squared bishop, but places their central pawns on d6 and e5 so that their remaining bishop is unimpeded. Garry Kasparov used it to great effect against Anatoly Karpov in their 1985 World Championship match. E50 – 4.e3 0-0 5.Nf3 d5 6.Bd3 c5 7.0-0 Nc6 8.a3 Bxc3 9.bxc3 dxc4 10.Bxc4 (includes Main Variation)
E78: The King's Indian Defence (or KID) is a common chess opening. It is defined by the following moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g6. Black intends to follow up with 3...Bg7 and 4...d6 (the Grünfeld Defence arises when Black plays 3...d5 instead and is considered a separate opening) 7.0-0 Na6 has seen some popularity recently. The purpose of this move is to transfer the knight to c5 after White's eventual d5, while guarding c7 if Black should play ...Qe8. After 7...a5 White plays 8.Bg5 to pin the knight, making it harder for Black to achieve the ...f7–f5 break. The Sämisch Variation is 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.f3. The game transposes into the Accelerated Dragon variation of the Sicilian Defence. Black has a variety of pawn breaks, such as ...e5, ...c5 and ...b5. 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Be2 0-0 6.Bg5 (named for Yuri Averbakh) The Four Pawns Attack is the most aggressive method for White. The Fianchetto Variation is named for White's development of light-squared bishop to g2. One of the earliest examples: John Cochrane vs. Bonnerjee Mohishunder, Calcutta, India, 1851 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 Bg7 4.e4 d6 5.Nge2 followed by 6.Ng3 is called the Hungarian Attack. Vladimir Bagirov–Eduard Gufeld, USSR championship 1973 "The Mona Lisa" at chessgames.comRetrieved from "https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=King%27s_Indian_Defence&oldid=1" E86 King's Indian, Sämisch, Orthodox, 7.Nge2 c6, 7...Nbd7, Main line.

A23: The English Opening is a chess opening that begins with the move:1.c4ECOA10–A39. It is one of the four most successful of White's twenty possible first moves. The English derives its name from leading 19th century English master Howard Staunton, who played it during his 1843 match with Saint-Amant. There are several types of positions that can arise from the Symmetrical Defence. The Hedgehog system involves a solid but flexible defence in which Black develops by b6, e6, Bb7, and Be7. The Reversed Sicilian (classified A20–29 in ECO) is another broad category of defence, introduced by the response 1...e5. All irregular responses like 1...b6 and 1...g5 are also lumped into this third broad category. 1...g5 is an eccentric response known as Myers' Defense after Hugh Myers's advocacy of it in print and actual play. It is intended as an improved Grob's Attack; after 2.d4, Black will put pressure on the d4-square with moves such as ...Bg7, ...c5, and ...Qb6. Black obtains no immediate compensation for the sacrificed pawn. The English Opening is used by Professor Moriarty in the film Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows as he and Holmes discuss their competing plans over a game of chess. It is also used in Pawn Sacrifice by Bobby Fischer in the climactic game six of the 1972 World Chess Championship versus Boris Spassky. C11: The French Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves 1.e4 e6 and 2.d4 d5. Black usually plays ...c5 soon after, attacking White's pawn centre and gaining space on the queenside. The French has a reputation for solidity and resilience. In the diagrammed position, Black most frequently plays 6...Ne7 (The main alternative is 6...Qc7, which can simply transpose to main lines after 7.Qg4 Ne7, but Black also has the option of 7. Qg4 f5 or ...f6). Now White can exploit the absence of Black's dark-square bishop by playing 7. qg4, giving Black two choices. 4...b6 followed by ...Ba6, or 4...Qd7 with the idea of meeting 5.Qg4 with 5...f5. Another popular way for Black to deviate is 4.e5 c5 5.a3 Ba5. Black maintains the pin on the knight, which White usually tries to break. The Steinitz Variation is named after Wilhelm Steinitz. The McCutcheon Variation was brought to public attention by John Lindsay McCUTcheon, who used it to defeat Steinitz in a simultaneous exhibition in Manhattan in 1885. After 3...dxe4, Black has the following options:The mainline 4...Nd7 (the most frequent high-level exponent of this variation is Georg Meier) 3...Nc6 is known as the Guimard Variation. 3...Nf6 aims to close the centre. 4...exd5 was a staple of many old Karpov–Korchnoi battles. It usually leads to Black having an isolated queen's pawn (see isolated pawn) The Advance Variation is the most difficult to play against due to the closed structure and unique strategies of the system. The main line is 3...c5 4.c3 Nc6 5.Nf3 and then we have a branching point:5...Qb6, the idea is to increase the pressure on d4 and eventually undermine the white centre. Despite the symmetrical pawn structure, White cannot force a draw. White will often play c2–c4 at some stage to put pressure on Black's d5-pawn. Black can give White an isolated queen's pawn by capturing on c4, but this gives White's pieces greater freedom. The French Defence is named after a match played by correspondence between the cities of London and Paris in 1834. Black usually replies 2...c5, after which play can resemble the 2.d3 variation or the Closed Variation of the Sicilian Defence. Play can continue 2...d5 3. e5 c5 4. Nf3 Nc6 5.c3 Nge7 6.Na3 Nf5. The Exchange Variation was recommended by Howard Staunton in the 19th century. In the early 1990s, Garry Kasparov briefly experimented with it before switching to 3.Nc3. It has the reputation of giving immediate equality to Black due to the symmetrical pawn structure. The Advance declined in popularity, however, throughout most of the 20th century until it was revived in the 1980s.
B63: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. In 1813, the English master Jacob Henry Sarratt effectively standardised his English translation of the name of this opening as 'the Sicilian defence' The Sicilian was fairly popular for much of the nineteenth century; Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais, Adolf Anderssen, Howard Staunton, Louis Paulsen, and Carl Jaenisch all played it with some consistency. It fell out of favour in the later part of the 19th century, when some of the world's leading players rejected it. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov popularised it in the 1980s and 1990s. 2.Na3 is an eccentric move recently returned to prominence by GM Vadim Zvjaginsev. Modern players would consider the notion that the Sicilian "prevents every attack" naive. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. 2.e5 gains space and prevents Black playing ...Nf6. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.nf3. The Tal Gambit Declined Archived 2012-06-24 at t at t.co.uk. The Grand International Masters' Tournament at St. Petersburg 1914, David McKay, c. 1915, p. 75.
D35: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5. In the Orthodox Line, Black will often aim for the pawn break ...c5 in this opening. 3...a6 (the Janowski Variation) gained some interest in 2021 after being adopted by World Champion Magnus Carlsen. The move threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. White has alternatives to 4.Nf3 such as the Marshall Gambit 4.e4. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense (from the white point of view) The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5. Peter Leko used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match.

D32: The Tarrasch Defense is a variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined. Black's third move is an aggressive bid for central space. After White plays cxd5 and dxc5, Black will be left with an isolated pawn on d5. This pawn may be weak, but it grants Black a foothold in the center. B01: Not to be confused with Scandinavian defence union. Opening is classified under code B01 in the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings. The general goal of the defense is to prevent White from controlling the center of the board with pawns, effectively forcing an open game. The retreat with 3...Qd8 was depicted in Castellvi–Vinyoles, the Valencian Variation. It was often considered the main line, and was characterized as "best" by Howard Staunton in his Chess-Player's Handbook. The line's reputation suffered after a string of defeats, including two well-known miniatures won by Bobby Fischer against Karl Robatsch in 1962. The Modern Variation is 3.d4, which can transpose into a variation of the Nimzowitsch Defense after 3...Nc6 (1.e4 Nc6 2. d4 d5 3.exd5 Qxd5), or Black can play 3...e5, as well. The other main branch of the Scandinavian Defense is 2...Nf6. The idea is to delay capturing the d5-pawn for another move. The Scandinavian Defense is one of the most popular chess openings. Black can play 3...c6, the Scandinavian Gambit, which is the most common move. White has several other options, including 3...Bb5+ Bd7, 3...Nbd7, and 4...Bc4.
B39: The Sicilian Defence is a chess opening that begins with the following moves:1.e4 c5ECOB20–B99OriginGiulio Cesare Polerio, 1594Named afterSicilyParentKing's Pawn Game. In 1813, the English master Jacob Henry Sarratt effectively standardised his English translation of the name of this opening as 'the Sicilian defence' The Sicilian was fairly popular for much of the nineteenth century; Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais, Adolf Anderssen, Howard Staunton, Louis Paulsen, and Carl Jaenisch all played it with some consistency. It fell out of favour in the later part of the 19th century, when some of the world's leading players rejected it. Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov popularised it in the 1980s and 1990s. 2.Na3 is an eccentric move recently returned to prominence by GM Vadim Zvjaginsev. Modern players would consider the notion that the Sicilian "prevents every attack" naive. The modern main line runs 2.Nc3 Nc6 3. f4 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7. 2.e5 gains space and prevents Black playing ...Nf6. White often supports the e5-pawn with 3.f4 or 3.nf3. The Tal Gambit Declined Archived 2012-06-24 at t at t.co.uk. The Grand International Masters' Tournament at St. Petersburg 1914, David McKay, c. 1915, p. 75.
B06: The Modern Defense is a hypermodern chess opening in which Black allows White to occupy the center with pawns on d4 and e4. Black then proceeds to attack and undermine this "ideal" center without attempting to occupy it. The opening has been most notably used by British grandmasters Nigel Davies and Colin McNab. After 2.Nf3, Black can play 2...c5, transposing to the Sicilian Defense, or 2...Bg7. Black can transpose to a closed Sicilian  with 2... c5 or play 2 ...Bg6. The Averbakh system is reached after 2...b7.
D50: The Queen's Gambit Declined is a chess opening in which Black declines a pawn offered by White. The Orthodox Line can be reached by a number of different move orders, such as 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5. In the Orthodox Line, Black will often aim for the pawn break ...c5 in this opening. 3...a6 (the Janowski Variation) gained some interest in 2021 after being adopted by World Champion Magnus Carlsen. The move threatens ...dxc4 followed by ...b5, attempting to hold on to the pawn. White has alternatives to 4.Nf3 such as the Marshall Gambit 4.e4. The Three Knights Variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined is usually reached from the move order 1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 d5 4.Nc3, played to avoid the Nimzo-Indian Defense (from the white point of view) The Vienna Variation occurs after Black plays 4...dxc4. An important line in this variation is the Endgame Line where the game continues. Placing the bishop on Bg5 allows Black to exchange more freely with moves like Nf6-e4. The move Bf4 is designed to restrict Black's opportunities in this way. Play usually continues with 5...0-0 6.e3 c5 7.dxc5 Bxc5. Peter Leko used this variation as White to beat Vladimir Kramnik in their 2004 World Championship Match.

D92: The Grünfeld Defence is a chess opening characterised by the moves:1. d4 Nf62. c4 g63. Nc3 d5. Black offers White the possibility of 4.cxd5, which may be followed by 4...Nxd5 and 5.e4. If White does not take the d5-pawn, Black may eventually play ...dxc4, when a White response of e4 again leads to the same pawn structure. In classical opening theory this imposing pawn centre was held to give White a large advantage, but the hypermodern school of chess held that a large pawn centre could be a liability rather than an asset. White can develop their pieces in a number of ways in the Exchange Variation. For decades, theory held that the correct method of  development was with Bc4 and Ne2, often followed by 0-0 and f4–f5, playing for a central breakthrough or kingside attack. In the late 1970s, however, Karpov, Kasparov and others found different methods to play the exchange with White. The Grünfeld Gambit is not often met in top-flight play today, its usage having declined significantly since its heyday in the 1930s. Despite its reputation, in statistical databases this variation shows only a slightly higher percentage of White wins and draws, as opposed to the Exchange Variation. Chessgames: Neo-Grünfeld 3.f3 is a 3.g3 version of the classic chess game. The game is played with the rules of the 3. f3 version. It is available in English and German.

B08: The Pirc Defence is a chess opening characterised by the response of Black to 1.e4 with 1...d6 and 2...Nf6, followed by ...g6 and ...Bg7. It allows White to establish a centre with pawns on d4 and e4. It is named after the Slovenian grandmaster Vasja Pirc. The Classical (Two Knights) System begins 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.Nf3 Bg7 5.Be2 0-0 6.0-0. The setup f2–f3, Be3 and Qd2 is commonly used against the King's Indian Defence and Dragon Sicilian. 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 d6 4.Bc4 Bg7 5.Qe2 is a sharp try for advantage; 5...Nc6 can lead to hair-raising complications after 6.e5. Black's best line may be 6...Ng4 7.e6 Nxd4 8.Qxg4 Nxc2+. Azmaiparashvili uses the Pirc to defeat reigning world chess champion Karpov. Kasparov vs. Veselin Topalov, Wijk aan Zee 1999, is called "the most famous Pirc game of all time" 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.f4 Bg7 5.Nf3 0-0 6.Be2 c5 7.dxc5 Qa5 8.0-0 Qxc5+ 9.Kh1 Nc6 10.Nd2 a5 11.Nb3 Qb6 12.a4 Nb4 13.e5 dxe5 14.Bxe5 Ne4 15.Nxe4 Bxe5 16.N f3 Bg3 17.Rad1 Qc8 18.Bc4 Be8 19.Neg5+ hxg5 20.Nxg 5+ Kg8 21.Qf4 Nd7 22.Rxd7 Bxf7+ 1–0.

D02: The London System is an opening system in chess where White opens with 1.d4 and develops the dark-squared bishop to f4. White then supports the d4-pawn with pawns on e3 and c3. The other bishop is developed to d3 (or occasionally e2) and the knights typically to f3 and d2. The London System can be used against virtually any Black defence and comprises a smaller body of opening theory than many other openings. White will typically post his king's knight on e5 and aim for a kingside attack. Black will typically aim for either ...e5 (after suitable preparation with Nbd7 and Re8) or ...c5 (in which case the game will resemble a Réti Opening with colours reversed) Other options for Black include mirroring White's play by also adopting the London System. Ding Liren vs. Ian Nepomniachtchi, Astana KAZ, World Championship 2023: 1.d4 Nf6 2.Nf3 d5 3.Bf4 c5 4.e3 Nc6 5.Nbd2 cxd4 6.exd4 Bf5 7.c3 e6 8.Bb5 Bd6 9.Bxd6 Qxd6 10.0-0 0-0 11.Re1 h6 12.Ne5 Ne7 13.a4 a6 14.BF1 Nd7 15.Nxd7 Qxd7 16.a5 Qc7 17.Qf3 Rfc8 18.Ra3 Bg6 19.Nb3 N c6 20.Qg3 Qe7 21.h4 Re8 22.Nc5 e5 23.Nxh4 dxe4 23.dxc5 b

D05: Not to be confused with Colley Matrix. Chess opening named after Edgard Colle. Common continuations include Nbd2 and 0-0.Movesfor White: d4, Nf3, e3, Bd3, c3ECOD05. The Colle System is also known as the Colle–Koltanowski System. One variation of the Colle is the ColLE–Zukertort System. It is characterised by developing the dark-squared bishop on b2. The typical plan is: 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 e6 3.e3 Nf6 4.Bd3 c5 5.0-0 Bd6 7.Bb2 0-0.

D33: The Tarrasch Defense is a variation of the Queen's Gambit Declined. Black's third move is an aggressive bid for central space. After White plays cxd5 and dxc5, Black will be left with an isolated pawn on d5. This pawn may be weak, but it grants Black a foothold in the center.
